articles.headline: On Anniversary of Katrina, Signs of Healing
articles.snippet: New Orleanians are optimistic about the future, but frustrated by the work that still needs to be done.
articles.abstract: New Orleanians are optimistic about the future, but frustrated by the work that still needs to be done.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  This city, not that long ago, appeared to be lost. Only five years have passed since corpses were floating through the streets, since hundreds of thousands of survivors sat in hotel rooms and shelters and the homes of relatives, learning from news footage that they were among the ranks of the homeless.

articles.headline: In Defense of Home Ownership
articles.snippet: Many home purchases could still end in grief financially, particularly in hard-hit areas. But most probably won’t.
articles.abstract: Many home purchases could still end in grief financially, particularly in hard-hit areas. But most probably won’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s hard to read the headlines and not conclude that becoming a homeowner is a terrible idea.

articles.headline: United-Continental Merger Clears Federal Hurdle
articles.snippet: With a Justice Department review finished, the airlines expect to complete their $3 billion merger within weeks.
articles.abstract: With a Justice Department review finished, the airlines expect to complete their $3 billion merger within weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said late Friday that it had cleared the planned $3 billion merger between United Airlines and Continental, lifting the biggest regulatory hurdle to the creation of the world’s top airline.

articles.headline: Vacation Travel Recovers, but Frugality Is Focus
articles.snippet: With pent-up demand comes a new level of austerity as vacationers search for frugal ways to get away.
articles.abstract: With pent-up demand comes a new level of austerity as vacationers search for frugal ways to get away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vacations have become a luxury for many Americans trying to make ends meet in this economic downturn, but there are signs that people are slowly, even timidly, on the move again.

articles.headline: Widespread Fear Freezes Housing Market
articles.snippet: Those dismal July housing figures were no blip, and signaled more bad news to come.
articles.abstract: Those dismal July housing figures were no blip, and signaled more bad news to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: You have to wonder sometimes what they’re smoking over there at the National Association of Realtors.

articles.headline: U.S. Wary of Example Set by Tribunal Case
articles.snippet: The White House is worried that the first case to go to trial under new rules could damage credibility among allies.
articles.abstract: The White House is worried that the first case to go to trial under new rules could damage credibility among allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After working for a year to redeem the international reputation of military commissions, Obama administration officials are alarmed by the first case to go to trial under revamped rules: the prosecution of a former child soldier whom an American interrogator implicitly threatened with gang rape.

articles.headline: Financier’s Largess Shows G.O.P.’s Wall St. Support
articles.snippet: Paul Singer, a hedge fund manager, has grown more influential as he and other conservatives tap into a rising tide of anger in the financial sector toward Washington.
articles.abstract: Paul Singer, a hedge fund manager, has grown more influential as he and other conservatives tap into a rising tide of anger in the financial sector toward Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a black-tie dinner in April, a politically influential hedge fund manager named Paul Singer offered a blistering critique of the “terrible path” he said Washington politicians were charting on economic issues.

articles.headline: U.N. Congo Report Offers New View on Genocide
articles.snippet: Rwandan troops and their rebel allies are said to have killed tens of thousands of members of the Hutu ethnic group, including civilians.
articles.abstract: Rwandan troops and their rebel allies are said to have killed tens of thousands of members of the Hutu ethnic group, including civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: A forthcoming United Nations report on 10 years of extraordinary violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo bluntly challenges the conventional history of events there after the 1994 Rwandan genocide, charging that invading troops from Rwanda and their rebel allies killed tens of thousands of members of the Hutu ethnic group, including many civilians.

articles.headline: In Hard Times, One New Bank (Double-Wide)
articles.snippet: The only new start-up bank to open in the United States this year operates out of a secondhand double-wide trailer, on a bare lot in Lake Charles, La.
articles.abstract: The only new start-up bank to open in the United States this year operates out of a secondhand double-wide trailer, on a bare lot in Lake Charles, La.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE CHARLES, La.  The only new start-up bank to open in the United States this year operates out of a secondhand double-wide trailer, on a bare lot in front of the cavernous Trinity Baptist Church. A blue awning covers the makeshift drive-through window.

articles.headline: Graft-Fighting Prosecutor Fired in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: One of Afghanistan’s top prosecutors said he was fired after he repeatedly refused to stop corruption inquiries.
articles.abstract: One of Afghanistan’s top prosecutors said he was fired after he repeatedly refused to stop corruption inquiries.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — One of the country’s most senior prosecutors said Saturday that President Hamid Karzai fired him last week after he repeatedly refused to block corruption investigations at the highest levels of Mr. Karzai’s government.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Hey, Big Spender: Hollywood Isn’t in the Mood
articles.snippet: How does Joel Silver, the producer behind “Die Hard” and “The Matrix,” adapt to a movie industry that is cutting costs?
articles.abstract: How does Joel Silver, the producer behind “Die Hard” and “The Matrix,” adapt to a movie industry that is cutting costs?
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Can Porsche Shine at Volkswagen?
articles.snippet: Volkswagen is poised to buy Porsche, a move that some people say could threaten the smaller carmaker’s high-end individuality.
articles.abstract: Volkswagen is poised to buy Porsche, a move that some people say could threaten the smaller carmaker’s high-end individuality.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEIPZIG, Germany

articles.headline: It’s Not Over Until It’s in the Rules
articles.snippet: During the rules-writing process for the financial overhaul, regulators will have to withstand pressure from big banks that want to keep control over the derivatives market.
articles.abstract: During the rules-writing process for the financial overhaul, regulators will have to withstand pressure from big banks that want to keep control over the derivatives market.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOW for the heavy lifting.

articles.headline: Upstarts Chip Away at Power of Pakistani Elite
articles.snippet: Pakistan is urbanizing fast, and powerful forces of change are chipping away at the landed aristocracy.
articles.abstract: Pakistan is urbanizing fast, and powerful forces of change are chipping away at the landed aristocracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUZAFFARGARH, Pakistan  In Pakistan, where politics has long been a matter of pedigree, Jamshed Dasti is a mongrel. The scrappy son of an amateur wrestler, Mr. Dasti has clawed his way into Pakistan’s Parliament, beating the wealthy, landed families who have ruled here.

articles.headline: For Obama, Steep Learning Curve as Chief in War
articles.snippet: The president has made war decisions after agonizing deliberation but also with dizzying swiftness, while he and the military have had a sometimes edgy relationship.
articles.abstract: The president has made war decisions after agonizing deliberation but also with dizzying swiftness, while he and the military have had a sometimes edgy relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama rushed to the Oval Office when word arrived one night that militants with Al Qaeda in Yemen had been located and that the military wanted to support an attack by Yemeni forces. After a quick discussion, his counterterrorism adviser, John O. Brennan, told him the window to strike was closing.

articles.headline: Sanofi’s Bid Puts Pressure on Genzyme
articles.snippet: The French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis disclosed its $18.5 billion bid for the American biotechnology firm Genzyme.
articles.abstract: The French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis disclosed its $18.5 billion bid for the American biotechnology firm Genzyme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, publicly disclosed its $18.5 billion bid for Genzyme on Sunday, intensifying pressure on the American biotechnology company to engage in discussions about a sale.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: China Fortifies State Businesses to Fuel Growth
articles.snippet: While China owes its rapid growth to private business, it is often the state’s companies that are on the march, in part because of state-bank financing and stimulus spending.
articles.abstract: While China owes its rapid growth to private business, it is often the state’s companies that are on the march, in part because of state-bank financing and stimulus spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  During its decades of rapid growth, China thrived by allowing once-suppressed private entrepreneurs to prosper, often at the expense of the old, inefficient state sector of the economy.

articles.headline: An Arms Sales Suspect, Bargaining With Secrets
articles.snippet: Officials believe Viktor Bout might be willing to trade his knowledge of criminal networks for a reduced sentence.
articles.abstract: Officials believe Viktor Bout might be willing to trade his knowledge of criminal networks for a reduced sentence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Accused of a 15-year run as one of the world’s biggest arms traffickers, Viktor Bout is thought to be a consummate deal maker.

articles.headline: Bernanke Manages Expectations for Fed Role
articles.snippet: The Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has made it clear that the Fed cannot simply conjure up a recovery.
articles.abstract: The Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has made it clear that the Fed cannot simply conjure up a recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  Federal Reserve officials and economists appear increasingly united in their view that the partisan gridlock on fiscal policy in Washington has clouded the prospects for a faster and stronger recovery.

articles.headline: Risk-Taking Rises as Oil Rigs in Gulf Drill Deeper
articles.snippet: As regulators investigate the causes of the Deepwater Horizon disaster, the broader dangers posed by the oil industry’s push into deeper waters have gone largely unscrutinized.
articles.abstract: As regulators investigate the causes of the Deepwater Horizon disaster, the broader dangers posed by the oil industry’s push into deeper waters have gone largely unscrutinized.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a remote reach of the Gulf of Mexico, nearly 200 miles from shore, a floating oil platform thrusts its tentacles deep into the ocean like a giant steel octopus.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Barry Meier

articles.headline: Retargeting Ads Follow Surfers to Other Sites
articles.snippet: Ads tailored to online shoppers based on the products they have perused are leaving consumers with an eerie feeling.
articles.abstract: Ads tailored to online shoppers based on the products they have perused are leaving consumers with an eerie feeling.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shoes that Julie Matlin recently saw on Zappos.com were kind of cute, or so she thought. But Ms. Matlin wasn’t ready to buy and left the site.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: In California, an Old-Style Print War
articles.snippet: Despite the many pressures on print media, the San Francisco weeklies The Bay Guardian and SF Weekly have been fighting for years over anticompetitive ad pricing.
articles.abstract: Despite the many pressures on print media, the San Francisco weeklies The Bay Guardian and SF Weekly have been fighting for years over anticompetitive ad pricing.
articles.lead_paragraph: San Francisco

articles.headline: Software War Pits Oracle vs. Google
articles.snippet: Now used by more big technology companies, open-source software has become a weapon in corporate warfare.
articles.abstract: Now used by more big technology companies, open-source software has become a weapon in corporate warfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: Free open-source software began with high-technology tinkerers and researchers. Sharing code and ideas was their priority, not profits. In the tech industry, they were sometimes compared to socialists and communists.

articles.headline: Technology Aside, Most People Still Decline to Be Located
articles.snippet: Mostly the young are interested in letting others know their physical location. Others are reticent for safety reasons, or against providing too much information.
articles.abstract: Mostly the young are interested in letting others know their physical location. Others are reticent for safety reasons, or against providing too much information.
articles.lead_paragraph: Internet companies have appropriated the real estate business’s mantra  it’s all about location, location, location.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Platinum Is So Passé. In iTunes Era, the Singles Count.
articles.snippet: The Billboard 200 chart is facing new competition in an era when artists can be a hit even if their albums aren’t.
articles.abstract: The Billboard 200 chart is facing new competition in an era when artists can be a hit even if their albums aren’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: By traditional measures, the British hip-hop artist Taio Cruz is far from being a star. But in the new world of pop music, he is certified gold.

articles.headline: Japan Plans New Steps to Curb Yen
articles.snippet: Analysts said that the new stimulus steps announced by the prime minister and the further easing of monetary policy were too timid.
articles.abstract: Analysts said that the new stimulus steps announced by the prime minister and the further easing of monetary policy were too timid.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan promised a host of measures on Monday in a bid to ignite its faltering economy and temper a punishingly strong yen.
